The physiological sigh involves understanding the intricate relationship between the brain, the body, and the respiratory system.
When we inhale, whether through the nose or mouth, the diaphragm moves down.
The diaphragm is a skeletal muscle responsible for breathing.
The diaphragm moving down allows the lungs to expand.
The expansion of the lungs provides more space for the heart.
This expansion causes the heart to grow slightly larger.
The blood within the heart moves more slowly in this increased volume.
The slowed blood flow is detected by specialized neurons in the heart.
These neurons are known as the sinoatrial node.
The sinoatrial node signals the brain that blood is flowing slower.
This signal prompts the brain to speed up the heart rate.
When we exhale, the diaphragm moves up, making the heart slightly smaller.
This results in blood flowing more quickly through the heart.
The sinoatrial node detects this accelerated blood flow and sends a signal to the brain.
The parasympathetic nervous system is located in the brainstem.
The parasympathetic nervous system sends signals back to the heart to slow down the heart rate in response.
By manipulating the length and vigor of our inhales and exhales, we can directly influence our heart rate and stress response.
To increase your heart rate, focus on longer and more vigorous inhales compared to exhales.
To decrease your heart rate and induce a sense of calmness, extend your exhales to make them longer and/or more vigorous than your inhales.
